comments.body: Has `NodeInodePressure` already been deprecated? If yes, add a link to it?
Good point! Opened https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/49103 to confirm whether we can remove it in 1.8 :).
nit: elsewhere we don't put empty line between the kube repo imports.
I know, and I find it confusing (especially when looking for `api/v1`).
I can revert this, but as an owner of NC I kind of feel that I should be able to add those:)
I wouldn't object if we followed the style here throughout the code base. Much easier to read instead of 30 apimachinery+client-go+apiserver+kube imports without structure.
We can fight it one file at a time;)

comments.body: How does this get resolved?  Or does it matter?  Most controllers assume they are active-passive, so there should be no other component.  Still, it might make sense to periodically reconcile our cache against all nodes?
should you "continue" here?
Right, I forgot that I'm actually using the Node in this handler. Good catch.
same question about "continue" as above
See above.
Do all of the taint add/remove operations in this PR retry on transient failure or at least become eventually consistent with the NodeStatus condition? That (obviously) seems impotant.
Yes. It is handled in the 'rate limited queue' - in case of failed Taint changes it will retry.

Same here.
You should probably create a separate PR where you change node controller to the pattern I described above (and that PR should be merged before this one).
See above.

I don't like the pattern of moving nil checks into the functions (if not necessary). I'll keep it on the higher level, guarded by `nc.taintManager != nil` everywhere which is not a create-related code.
I don't think we need to make taintManager conditional. If it is broken we will do a patch release. Making it unconditional will simplify the code.
There is a GET in L453, you probably want to switch that to a cache lookup too. Also it seems that you want to deep-copy in certain places inside `tryUpdateNodeStatus`.

For the line 453 - since this is retry, I'm on purpose doing get from etcd there - this is to decrease probability for conflicts in those situations.

Regarding the DeepCopy - yes, that's a good point. I will add it.

This one should also be removed.
@davidopp
Github is so stupid that it cannot detect that it's actually not a new code...
[ignoring whitespace](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/34851/files?w=1) makes it better
@liggitt How did you do that? (yes it's much better)
add `?w=1` to the end of the URL
nice trick - I didn't know about it. Thanks!
Are we sure that len(v) > 0 here?
Yes, if it were 0, then there would be no Nodes in the given zone, and hence the zone would not exist. This map is created from scratch each time `monitorNodeStatus` is called.

comments.body: Please state explicitly that the problem is that in memory an unoccupied CIDR is marked as occupied, which prevents it from being allocated to something. But the state of the cluster itself is correct.
Done.

func(defaultQPS float32) RateLimitedTimedQueue

comments.body: nc.setLimiterInZone(...)
This case is not handled, as it's a special logic for complete isolation of master.
Can we merge these two loops into one?
Done.
should there be return here?
Done.

Actually the previous "if" consists of:
- setting probe times
- the same code as here

We should merge those two together.
Not that simple. In this loop we only modify limiters for zones which changed states, above we force update everywhere.
We should remove zones (from nc.zoneState) that no longer exist (i.e. zones which all nodes have already been removed).
Right. I was overwriting whole list it originally, but I forgot to update it after I changed the logic.
Shouldn't we set up ns.zonePodEvictor for this zone?

I don't think we need to. This "Initial" state is only a temporary previous one. It will assure that we won't have `allWasFullyDisrupted == true`, so we'll always enter the main if stmt. In it we'll either enter 'allAreFullyDisruptedBranch' and set the rate limiter there, or an ordinary loop, which will also set the limiter, as new state will be different than "Initial".
s/zoneTerminationEvictor/zonePodEvictor/

Or maybe you should even do (performance is not important in this case):

```
for _, evictor := range nv.zonePodEvictor {
  evictor.Try(...

     evictor.Add(...)
)
```
Discussed f2f
And the same here
Discussed f2f
Why you are iterating over all zones - shouldn't you only look into zone in which the node is?
This is the current logic.
Shouldn't you update zoneStates here?
Yeah, it had to got lost in last rewriting of this part.
You will get here if GetByKey returns an error.  Also, is it possible for the cache to be stale?

GetByKey, can't return errors stupidly. That should be cleaned up:

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/client/cache/store.go#L192

I'll do this in a follow up.

These cashes can be stale. There's a race here if a (node get's created -> scheduler get's update of node -> new pod gets assigned to a node -> controller get's update of pod) before (node get's created -> controller get's update of node). It seems less likely and of smaller consequence then the bug this fixes. Any suggestion on how to work around this?
Also the node has to become ready in the scheduler flow and doesn't have to become ready in the controller manager flow which also makes the race less likely. Still a race though.

My intuition is that this race is pretty minor and less significant than the bug it fixes, but our intuition is often wrong about this stuff, and on an antagonistically loaded machine, you could imagine being in some kind of steady state forever where the controllers fight each other.

But there's a non-controller behavior that's also new.  If I manually specify a host in my single pod (no controller), but make a typo, my pod disappears and never runs.  That'll seem weird.  It's also possible for the user to submit the pod in the same race window (hard to imagine this really happening) and the same thing happens.

Suggestions for fixing the race... I'll think about it.  Concurrency + global state + caching lends itself to this.
I'm not quite sure how it'll interact with mirror pods... @yujuhong

If kubelet is semi-functioning, it may try to recreate the mirror pods. You'll be left with running pods on a node that doesn't exist anymore. Since this PR deletes pods/nodes only when the vm has disappeared, it should be fine.
defer util.HandleCrash()
Done.

Let me rephrase my question (I'd love to attach it to 'forcefullyDeletePod' function, but github...): how does force-deleting (GracePeriodSeconds=0) work on mirror pods and/or daemon pods. @yujuhong @mikedanese. Will it correctly delete it from the API server and it won't come back, or they'll get recreated and we'll have a race condition here?
Sorry - this has nothing to do with this PR. It's a problem for 'normal' Node eviction, but in your case it's OK.
I was just suggesting adding to terminationEvictor here, instead of invoking `terminatePods`.

That's what I had this morning, but @gmarek convinced me otherwise. We don't expect any _actual_ pods to be running, though they may still be represented in the apiserver. If I understand the system, it should come out fine whether we queue or directly terminate. 

If we try to directly terminate and it fails for whatever reason, we'll bail, but next scan through the nodes we should attempt to evict/terminate again.

If we add to the evictor queue, we might get more retries before the next full node scan, but we may also be backing up the rate-limited piece for no good reason.

If that description doesn't match with what you think would actually happen, I'm happy to change the PR.

Yup - I don't think that rate limiting makes any sense here. This is a branch responsible for evicting Pods from Nodes that are gone from the cloud provider's perspective. If for whatever reason we would be able to contact this Node it would mean that there's some serious bug in the control plane of the given provider.
That feels scary. If there was a meaningful update in between my read and write, wouldn't I clobber it?
Yes - it would.

I'm not very familiar with the ResourceEventHandlers, but I don't think this would handle crashes/restarts well.

E.g., if the nodeController restarts, it is possible that the next new node is issued a CIDR that was previously issued to someone else, right?
if the nodeController restarts, ResourceEventHandlers would observe some Add Event. So we need mark the CIDR has been occupied if `node.Spec.PodCIDR != ""`, sorry for the missing.

If this happens, do we retry?

Can we also log the error?
Probably need some sort of retry here too.

I have no idea how to implement the retry logic, since `AllocateNext()`has search through the range to find available ones. If `AllocateNext()` failed, it will fail again (unless a node be deleted and its podCIDR be released during retry). If we want add the retry logic here, may be my first version of this PR(using channel and timeout) is much better. Do you have any thoughts?
This is fine how it is. It's definitely no worse than what we have now.
Would be nice to log the error from the failed update.
godoc style: translateCIDRs does

Add the same TODO as in generateCIDRs: `// TODO: Make the CIDRs configurable.`

Also delete generateCIDRs, as it should be unused now.

What if two Nodes have the same CIDR for some reason (e.g. one Node got disconnected for an hour but came back)? We'll generate all CIDRs and fall back to reassigning CIDR to one of them. As we're generating CIDRs in order can we check if we're in the range of 'known' ones?

Sorry, I am a little bit confused about the case you described. Do you mean if one Node got disconnected when we running the nc.needSync code(above code), its CIDR will not be deleted from the availableCIDRs set and may be reassign to another Node? If this is the case, it will be a little bit complicated. You are right, if we simply check the CIDR range of known nodes, it could be solved. But it will waste a lot of CIDRs for example, we have 1000 nodes at first and delete the first 999 nodes and then restart the node_controller. In this case, the first 999 CIDRs will be wasted and we will start assigning from 1001st CIDR.

The other solution will be maintaining a bool array to mark if that CIDR has been used. As you comment below, we currently has 3072 CIDRs in default setup and it will be ok to maintain a bool array(since we will use less than 1MB memory). It will both simplify the code and solve this problem, I will update the code in this way. Thanks

Sorry, you're right. I was thinking about the scenario when Node becomes unresponsive and comes back again. But either we'll delete Node object for it, and everything will need to be recreated from the start, or it won't be deleted, and nothing else will get CIDR assigned to it.
can you make this []bool?

Or let's forget about this comment. It's probably not worth the effort. Hash maps are generally expensive, AFAIK go implementation uses roughly x30 of the size of key-value, but this would put us in still reasonable amount of 4 \* 30 \* 3072 = 360kB.

Not sure why this method is in a poll loop instead of triggered by a watch (not your problem, just saying), there's a chance it will still not realize as soon as a node falls off the netowork so the reboot test (the one that needs the pods to become not ready) can still fail.  How often does this poll loop run?
Looks like it runs every 5 seconds... The timeout for node notready is 40 secs. So the worst case is 45 secs to flip node to notready.
I could have sworn we already had code somewhere that deleted pods that are on nodes that no longer exist, but it wasn't in the GC controller so maybe I'm just hallucinating?

You are hallucinating. It's one of your left to do bullets.

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/7660#issuecomment-146079112

We don't - we opened an issue to add it.

comments.body: I'd call variable timedNodeName, or something else more descriptive than plain 'value'. Same below.

The queue was intended to be generic enough to reuse (it's useful for any
client code that wants to wait X time before retrying an item again, like
controllers if a retry is needed), could be an interface{} but that was
more changes.

Yes, TimedValue as a type is OK, I'm saying that the variable name can be more descriptive. At first I wasn't certain if Value stores Node name or Pod name.
You can return false, err here.
`remaining` is a really bad name for this variable.
Is this backward compatible? IIUC `DeletionGracePeriodSeconds` was introduced quite recently, and thus will be `nil` in all 'upgraded' clusters.

Do we really want to share the same RateLimiter between podeEvictor and terminationEvictor? I'm not against it, but in general I don't like sharing state if it gives nothing except coding convenience.

I think they are effectively the same pool - the goal seems to be to
prevent the node controller from slaughtering the master during
negotiations eviction, and delete and terminate are two parts of the same
process.  Up to you, they don't seem separate to me.

comments.body: I think there's still a (small) window for a race here, between deleting pods and deleting the node the scheduler could assign new pods to this node.
Wont the Scheduler not assign pods to nodes with readyCondition.Status != api.ConditionTrue?
That could be (I don't know much about the scheduler internals).

There's still going to be a race, since we don't know when the scheduler has observed the condition.

Also, it looks like monitorNodeStatus doesn't delete pods at all.
That race is super unlikely, as the lag between not ready and node deletion is typically 5 minutes.
Since you're modifying knowNodeSet here, can you please remove "oldSize" and "addedNodes" - these are not needed now.

It's for quick check if we deleted something or not. Difference of sets is slower. If you already mentioned it, I'd rather move construction of observedSet into the second if, as it'll be rather rare (hopefully)

But you can do:
"if len(ns.knownNodeSet) != len(nodes.Items)"

It would be exactly the same.
Done.
